Vision Loss

  • Papillitis - Optic disc inflammation. May be unilateral.
  • Papilledema - Optic disc edema specifically due to increased intracranial pressure. It is most often bilateral.
  • Retrobulbar optic neuritis - Optic neuritis involving the optic nerve behind the globe. Depending on which part of the optic nerve is involved, papillitis may not be present.
  • Neuroretinitis - Inflammatory process involving the optic discs with exudative changes in the nerve fiber layer of the retina (macular star). This is not associated with demyelinating disease.

Anisocoria Evaluation

Approach to Unequal Pupils

Key question: Which pupil is abnormal ‚Äî the large one or the small one?

EMERGENCY: Large pupil + ptosis + eye "down and out" = CN III palsy until proven otherwise. In a post-operative or head-injured patient, this may indicate uncal herniation requiring emergent neurosurgical evaluation.

Step 1: Examine in Light vs Dark

  • Anisocoria greater in light (large pupil doesn't constrict) ‚Üí problem is with the large pupil
    • CN III palsy (check for ptosis, eye movement limitation)
    • Pharmacologic mydriasis (topical atropine/cyclopentolate ‚Äî won't constrict to 1% pilocarpine)
    • Traumatic mydriasis (iris sphincter damage)
    • Tonic pupil (Adie) ‚Äî vermiform movements, slow constriction, constricts to dilute 0.1% pilocarpine (denervation supersensitivity)
  • Anisocoria greater in dark (small pupil doesn't dilate) ‚Üí problem is with the small pupil
    • Horner syndrome (ptosis + miosis ¬± anhidrosis)
    • Pharmacologic miosis
  • Anisocoria equal in light and dark (~0.5-1mm) ‚Üí physiologic anisocoria (present in ~20% of population, no workup needed)

Horner Syndrome Workup

Confirm: Topical 4% cocaine or 0.5% apraclonidine ‚Äî Horner pupil fails to dilate with cocaine (or reverses with apraclonidine).

Localize:

  • Central (1st order): Stroke, demyelination, tumor ‚Äî MRI brain + cervical spine
  • Preganglionic (2nd order): Pancoast tumor, neuroblastoma (pediatric!), carotid dissection ‚Äî CT/MRI chest + neck
  • Postganglionic (3rd order): Carotid dissection, cavernous sinus lesion ‚Äî MRA head/neck

Pediatric Horner: Must rule out neuroblastoma (obtain urine catecholamines ‚Äî HVA, VMA) and birth-related brachial plexus injury in infants. New-onset Horner in any age ‚Üí imaging mandatory.

CN III Palsy ‚Äî Surgical vs Medical

  • "Surgical" (pupil-involving): Mydriasis + ptosis + limited adduction/elevation/depression ‚Üí concern for posterior communicating artery (PComm) aneurysm compression. Urgent CTA/MRA.
  • "Medical" (pupil-sparing): Ptosis + eye movement limitation but normal pupil ‚Üí microvascular (diabetes, hypertension). More common in adults; rare in children.
  • In children: Pupil-sparing distinction is less reliable. Any CN III palsy in a child warrants imaging.
